newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks pull back from "samba effect".
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks pull back from "samba effect".

text.p: Mexican stocks rebounded sharply at the close Wednesday from a heady dive during the prior session.
Dealers and analysts said buyers returned to the market to hunt bargains as fears subsided of contagion from a possible devaluation and fire sale in Brazilian financial markets.
"Yesterday's slide was due to Brazil rather than domestic fundamentals, and that means things look better in the long run," said Roberto Garcia, a fund manager at the Vector brokerage.
Final closing prices showed the blue-chip IPC share index was up 93.08 points, or 1.98 percent, at 4,787.43.
"Today's rebound was more than just technically grounded, it shows a return of market confidence," said Hector Jimenez, an analyst with the Inverlat brokerage.
"We reacted in tandem with other markets, a sort of domino effect," Jimenez added, referring to rallies in New York and Brazil. "Bancomer and Telmex hauled us up.
The Bovespa index of most active stocks traded in Sao Paulo ended up up 8.81 percent at 12,641 points. The Dow Jones, meanwhile, soared 63.17 points to a record close of 8,038.88.
Dealers said brisk trading volume of 114 million shares underpinned the strong presence of buyers in the market.

Financial firm Bancomer climbed 33 centavos (4 centavos) to 4.38 pesos (56 cents) and telecommunications company Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) ended up 35 centavos (4.5 cents) at 20.65 pesos ($2.62). The two stocks together accounted for almost 30 percent of all shares traded during the session. Telmex American Depositary Receipts rose 1-7/16 to end at 52-1/4.
Garcia said some brokers began to position themselves ahead of second-quarter earnings reports expected in the coming days.
"Players with liquidity on their hands took advantage of the slide to pick up bargains. All we have on the horizon now are Q2 earnings," he said.
"They are stepping into food, beverages, tobacco, construction and transportation," he added.

Beverage firm Fondo Economico Mexicano was near the head of the prominent gainers' list after rising 4.30 pesos (55 cents) to 53.00 pesos ($6.73) in brisk trade. Construction firm Tribasa also traded strongly and advanced 1.30 pesos (16 cents) to 24.60 pesos ($3.12).
On the broad market, gainers outpaced sliders by 85 to 21, out of a total of 124 stocks that changed hands.
